title-group.article-title: Troubleshooting coextrusion film problems by considering process–property relationships*

article-meta.aff: DuPont Packaging and Industrial Polymers, Wilmington, DE, USA

abstract.p: Coextrusion of plastics into a multilayer film is a complex process where many processing and structure design factors affect performance. As a result, problems can be difficult to troubleshoot. We describe issues involving estimating properties from monolayer films, achieving good interlayer adhesion and minimizing curl. Multilayer film properties such as gas permeation and bending stiffness cannot be estimated from simply adding up the properties of monolayer films of the individual layers. Properties may also differ from their monolayer analogs due to differences in stress and temperature history during coextrusion. Some combinations of polymers may not be possible to make due to flow instabilities. Many polymers used in multilayer films do not adhere well to one another. Tie resins have been developed to promote adhesion, but many factors affect their peel strength performance, including fabrication parameters. More so than monolayer films, coextrusion films are prone to curling or rolling up on themselves. Factors such as differential shrinkage during quenching play a role. This paper explores some of the recent advances in the science of coextrusion and how this knowledge can be used to address these issues.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Coextrusion was developed in the 1970s and 1980s as an economical way to combine the properties of different resins to achieve desired performance criteria. For example, in the food packaging industry, barrier polymers (such as ethylene vinyl alcohol (EVOH) or polyamide (PA)) are combined with structural layers (such as polyethylene (PE) or polypropylene (PP)) and sealant layers (such as ethylene vinyl acetate (EVA), polyethylene plastomers (mPE) or ionomers).1 Hundreds of different combinations of materials are now made commercially with increasing complexity. While three to five layers was the norm in the early days, seven, nine and even higher layers are now common. Layer multiplier technology also allows all or some of the layers to be spit into many ‘micro’ or ‘nano’ layers.2–6

In the early days, development was empirical. Over the past four decades, however, the science has begun to catch up with the technology. An example is the work by Dooley and coworkers at Dow Chemical Company exploring the effect of polymer elasticity on flow in dies.7 One wonders if we would even have a coextrusion industry today if the complexities that have been discovered over the years were known in the beginning.

This article discusses some of the unique issues associated with designing and producing coex film structures. We will review the science behind these issues beginning with comparing multilayer and monolayer processes, followed by adhesion and curl. We end with some examples of how this knowledge might be used to troubleshoot or even prevent the occurrence of surprises and problems during production.

sec.title: Coex versus monolayer film properties
sec.p: A key question for anyone designing a new coextrusion film is whether monolayer film properties can be used to estimate coex film properties. There are three aspects to this question: (1) How does the coex structure affect the final film properties? (2) Does the coex process itself affect the properties? (3) Are there limitations on what can be made?

sec.title: Multilayer film design
sec.p:
Properties of multilayer films do not usually follow from simply adding up the properties of the individual layers. Gas permeation, for example, follows an inverse mean relationship similar to electrical conductance in a series of resistors in an electrical circuit (1)1OTR=th1OPV1+th2OPV2+th3OPV3+… where
OTR = oxygen transmission for the package
thi = thickness of layer i
OPVi = oxygen permeation value for layer i

The stiffness or strength of a film is also nonlinear. A critical property in many flexible film applications is the bending stiffness, which depends on the thickness, tensile modulus and location of each of the layers. Simply rearranging layers can have a substantial effect on bending stiffness. An example that illustrates this is given in Figure 1.8 Here we consider four 25 µm thick layers, two made from a relatively stiff high density polyethylene (HDPE) and two from a flexible mPE plastomer. Changing the structure from the HDPE layers as the core to the skins increases the bending stiffness by a factor of four! This type of relationship can be predicted from beam theory.8 Once we understand the theory behind this effect, we can use this to redesign structures that maintain stiffness when downgauged. Figure 1.
Example of effect of layer distribution on bending stiffness.
HDPE: high density polyethylene; mPE: metallocene polyethylene plastomer.

sec.title: Effect of coex process
sec.p:
Some properties can be affected by the coex process itself. An example comes from blown film.9 The polymer is extruded into a tube and subsequently stretched in the machine and transverse directions as the polymer is cooled. Most of the orientation in mono layer blown film occurs near the frost line where the polymer starts to freeze.10–18 This orientation contributes to many of the properties of the film. Morris9 and Giriprasath19 found that in coex blown film, the layer that freezes first dictates the shape and velocity profile in the bubble and hence the stress/temperature history of all the layers. What this means is that the other layers see less stress during orientation since the orientation occurs at temperatures well above their freezing points (Tf). This can affect properties through changes in crystalline morphology and residual stress. Figure 29 shows the effect on transverse direction (TD) tear for HDPE films made via mono layer film blowing and coex with EVOH (where the EVOH layer is removed prior to testing). EVOH has a higher Tf than HDPE and so freezes first. Figure 2.
Effect of coextrusion of tear properties of HDPE film.
HDPE: high density polyethylene; MD: machine direction; TD: transverse direction.

The coextrusion process may also limit the materials that can be used or their thickness/location in the structure due to flow instability. It is well known that the viscosity of adjacent layers needs to be well matched to avoid flow instabilities that show up as film imperfections. Elasticity and flow geometry also play a role.20–33 One guideline is to choose resins whose viscosities are within a factor of three of each other. Viscosity of most polymers is a function of shear rate or shear stress. This relationship differs for each polymer. The shear stress varies linearly within a flow channel, so the location of the interface can affect the viscosity ratio. Hence the layer thickness and location may affect the ability to make structures without flow instabilities.

sec.title: Adhesion
sec.p: The coextrusion process and the structure design influence the adhesion between layers. This in turn can affect the properties of the film. In most cases good interlayer adhesion is desired to achieve optimum properties. But in some situations, controlled adhesion is needed. For example, some easy open sealant films are designed to tear through the sealant layer and fail along the interface with the adjacent layer. Tear and puncture resistance may also benefit from controlled adhesion at the interfaces: energy may be dissipated as the layers delaminate during tearing or puncture, but too little adhesion results in premature delamination.

Many resins used in coex film structures do not bond well to each other, as illustrated in Figure 3. For these combinations, tie resins are used to adhere the layers. Tie resins are generally designed to take advantage of either diffusion or chemical interaction to achieve good adhesion. If the tie resin is compatible with one of the substrates, with enough time and temperature the molecular chains will diffuse across the interface. The resulting chain entanglements, co-crystallization and molecular forces such as van der Waals forces provide strength at the interface. For those substrates that are not compatible, chemical functionality is added to the tie resin to promote a chemical bond with the substrate. Figure 3.
Combinations of commonly used polymers in coextrusion films often do not bond well.
EVOH: ethylene vinyl alcohol copolymer; HDPE: high density polyethylene; LDPE: low density polyethylene; EVA: ethylene vinyl acetate copolymer.

An example of a typical tie layer is shown in Figure 4. Here we are looking at bonding PE to PA or EVOH. A maleic anhydride modified polyethylene or ethylene copolymer is often used. Diffusion occurs at the PE–tie interface whereas a chemical interaction between the anhydride groups of the tie resin and the amine end groups of PA or the hydroxyl groups of EVOH occurs at the tie-PA or EVOH interface. Figure 4.
Tie layer technology.
PE: polyethylene; EVOH: ethylene vinyl alcohol copolymer.

Adhesion is influenced by many material parameters, such as the type of polyolefin or copolymer and the amount and type of chemical functionality in the tie resin, as well as the chemistry of the bonding substrate.34 The thicknesses of the tie and substrate layers also play a role. Examples are shown in Figures 5 and 6.34 Perhaps not surprising is that the process dictates the physical limit as to how thin the tie layer can be and still maintain uniform thickness and functionality. The mechanics of the adhesion measurement may be a limiting factor as well.35 Adhesion is typically determined with a peel test which measures the energy to pull the specimen apart. The peel strength is a function of the energy to bend and elongate the peel arm in addition to the energy to create new surfaces (known as the fracture energy). All three energies are influenced by thickness. In some cases, as a structure is downgauged, a different tie layer may be required to achieve the desired peel strength due to these limitations. Figure 5.
Example of the effect of tie layer thickness on peel strength performance.

Figure 6.
Example of the effect of substrate thickness on peel strength performance. Measurement is peel strength to the EVOH layer.
LDPE: low density polyethylene; tie: tie resin; EVOH: ethylene vinyl alcohol; PE: polyethylene.

The coextrusion process and its process parameters can have a significant effect on peel strength. Figure 7 shows the peel strength to EVOH of several different tie resins for cast and blown film.36 (The cast film was made with a feedblock and flat die.) Each tie resin contains anhydride functionality. The peel strength is plotted versus the process time, a fundamental parameter characterizing the time the polymer spends after the die exit before being quenched. For cast film, the process time is the time in the air gap since the film rapidly freezes upon contact with the chill roll. For blown film it is the time between the die exit and the frost line. Morris36 developed the formulae for computing the process time and explains the different time scales for the two processes and their influence on peel strength. Of particular interest is the fact that the same tie resin gives different peel strength values in the two processes. Morris36 was able to collapse all the data onto a single master curve using an engineering analysis (Figure 8). In this way we can relate the peel strength performance to material properties of the tie resin (such as modulus) and the time, temperature and stress history during coextrusion. Figure 7.
Example of blown and cast film peel strength results.
BF: blown film; CF: cast film; EVA: ethylene vinyl acetate; LLDPE: linear low density polyethylene; mLLDPE: metallocene linear low density polyethylene.
Figure 8.
Process time curve.
BF: blown film; CF: cast film; EVA: ethylene vinyl acetate; LLDPE: linear low density polyethylene; mLLDPE: metallocene linear low density polyethylene.

Some of the implications of this analysis are
Tie resins behave differently in different processes. The best tie resin for cast film may not be the best tie resin for blown film.
Increasing the processing temperature generally increases the peel strength. One reason for this is the boost in initial adhesion as the layers come into contact in the die. Another is what happens after the die. In Figure 8, the temperature effect is embedded in the characteristic relaxation time.36 The relaxation time decreases with increasing temperature, moving the point on the curve to the right to higher values of peel strength.
Increasing the process time increases the peel strength. Since process time is inversely related to output, increasing output may decrease peel strength.

The last point is further illustrated in Figure 9 where the process time curve is replotted in terms of output.36 Figure 9.
Effect of output on adhesion in coextrusion coating.

A number of other factors influence adhesion in coextrusion,34 including the conditions the film is subjected to in its end use, such as heat or chemicals. In any coex film development it is important to test the film under conditions of its ultimate use.

sec.title: Curl
sec.p: Multilayer films may have a tendency to roll up on themselves or curl. Roll tension and other factors play a role, but the interaction of the structure design and the converting process can be a significant factor. When layers are made of materials with different amounts of shrinkage, due to differences in crystallization or thermal expansion coefficients, curl can be the result. Once the first layer freezes the other layers shrink against it and curl the film towards the layer that shrinks the most unless this is compensated by the stiffness and shrinkage of the other layers. For example, in a barrier snack package with the structure (HDPE–tie–EVOH–tie–EVA) the EVOH freezes first followed by the HDPE. As the HDPE freezes it shrinks due to its relatively high amount of crystallinity. The EVA shrinks last but is not stiff enough or crystalline enough to counteract the curl towards the HDPE.

Structural and processing changes may be considered to reduce the curl. The first step is to find out which direction the curl is facing. This can be accomplished by cutting an X in the film and seeing in which direction the film rolls up – machine or transverse direction and towards which outside layer. Adjusting the blow-up ratio in blown film may help balance the curl if it is primarily in one direction or the other. Faster quench rates typically reduce the curl by lowering the amount of crystallinity and reducing the crystallization temperature. Cast film and water quench blown film processes typically produce less curl than blown film.

There may be ways to balance out the materials in the structure to neutralize the curl. The composition of the tie resins may be used to help balance out the structure, but often the tie layer is too thin to make a major impact. Balancing the stiffness of the layers may also help. Sometimes changing the sealant layer can help. Ionomer sealants anecdotally have been said to give less curl than EVA or LLDPE. In a recent study done for a customer, we made several 7-layer structures on a coex blown film line with the nominal composition: (sealant–tie–PA–EVOH–PA–tie–PA). Changing tie resin compositions from EVA to LLDPE had little impact, but switching from a LLDPE sealant to an ionomer changed the curl from very tight to essentially flat.

Morris37 developed a mathematical model for predicting curl that was useful in developing new cereal liner structures that reduced curl. The model uses beam theory to determine if differential shrinkage during quenching can be balanced by the stiffness and thickness of the layers. Differential shrinkage amongst the various layers is determined from a series of 2-layer coextrusion experiments. Such a semi-empirical approach can provide guidance in alleviating curl problems.

sec.title: Case studies
sec.p: To illustrate these points, consider the following examples based on field experience with dealing with coex film issues.

sec.title: Adhesion issue
sec.p: A blown film converter makes a five layer film with the following structure: (PA6–tie–PA6–EVOH–PA6–tie–ionomer). The converter obtains good interlayer adhesion during the development of the structure but encounters failures after they scale-up to full production.

Upon analysis, the following facts are brought out:
Failure is due to delamination between the inside tie layer and PA6.
Initial development was done on a coex blown film line with 6-in. diameter die and no inner bubble cooling.
Full production is on a 14-in. diameter die with inner bubble cooling.
Process time computed for the development and production processes is 3 and 0.5 s, respectively.

Because of the faster production rates and inner bubble cooling on the production line, the process time is considerably lower. This moves them down the process time curve (Figure 9) to lower levels of peel strength. Switching to a higher performance tie resin should solve the problem.

sec.title: Downgauging
sec.p:
A film converter makes a slug pack film for snack food packaging on a coex blown film line. The structure is (HDPE–tie–PA6–tie–EVA). They would like to downgauge the structure to meet their customer’s sustainability goals. Some considerations:
The HDPE layer provides moisture barrier. There may be new grades of HDPE with lower MVTR to consider. This should be done in close consultation with their resin supplier. A more crystalline HDPE may increase the barrier but may also increase the curl. The PA6 will freeze first in this structure, followed by the HDPE. As described above, the orientation and crystalline structure of the HDPE layer may differ from monolayer HDPE films. The effect this may have on barrier performance, stiffness and curl needs to be considered.
The PA6 core layer is providing aroma and oxygen barrier. EVOH is a more effective barrier. There may be an opportunity to switch to a thinner layer of EVOH. Key questions are whether the converting equipment will allow the EVOH to be made thin enough to compensate for the increased cost. The size of the extruder for the core layer and the design of the die play a role in this. Switching to EVOH may also require changing to a more expensive tie resin. Curl could be an issue as well.
The EVA layer is providing low temperature sealability, allowing fast packing speeds without distorting the HDPE layer. It may be formulated for easy open functionality. Often the sealant layer is 25% to 30% of a snack package structure. Simply reducing the thickness of this layer may cause problems with sealing as well as result in a film that is perceived as being more flimsy by the consumer. One option is to switch to an ionomer sealant. Ionomers have low temperature sealability but with outstanding hot tack that may allow them to be downgauged without affecting seal performance. They have much higher stiffness than EVA and so may allow the total thickness of the structure to be reduced without affecting the bending stiffness.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: There are a number of unique factors when dealing with the design and production of coextruded films, including film properties, adhesion and curl, that are not present in monolayer films. By better understanding the science behind these factors we can better anticipate and correct potential problems in production.

bio.title: Biography
bio.p: Barry A Morris is a technical fellow with DuPont Packaging and Industrial Polymers working in the area of new polymer/application development. He received a BS in Chemical Engineering from the University of Virginia and a PhD from Princeton University. He also has a MBA from the University of Delaware. His research interests include polymer adhesion, blends, compounding, rheology, and co-extrusion film and coating converting processes.
